results.title: Play misty for me [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Clint Eastwood, Robert Daley, Malpaso Company and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: In this contemporary thriller, Clint Eastwood plays the popular California disc jockey, Dave Garland. On his radio show he repeatedly receives a phone request for “Play Misty for Me”, from a feminine voice. Garland meets the owner of the mysterious voice, Evelyn Draper, at a night spot he frequents. Unsuspecting, he takes her home with him and there the terror begins. Stars Jessica Walter, Donna Mills and John Larch. Photographed by Bruce Surtees. Screenplay by Jo Heims and Dean Riesner. “Misty” composed and performed by Erroll Garner.

results.title: Cape fear (1991) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Barbara de Fina, Tribeca Productions, Cappa Films, Amblin Entertainment and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Master filmmaker Scorcese tackled the re-make of the original 1962 classic with resounding success. Cape Fear is more than a journey towards terror and death. Fourteen years after being imprisoned, vicious psychopath Cady, played chillingly by Robert De Niro, emerges with a single-minded mission: to seek revenge on his attorney Sam Bowden, (Nick Nolte). His purpose, to upset the fragile equilibrium of Sam’s family life with his wife, (Jessica Lange), and teenage daughter, (Juliette Lewis), escalates until their very lives are threatened. Ultimately, Sam has to resort to unorthodox measures, but cannot escape the ultimate showdown in the murky, stormy waters of Cape Fear. Visually stunning images, and brilliant performances, plus cameo roles from original cast members (Gregory Peck, Robert Mitchum and Martin Balsam) highlight this roller-coaster ride through relentless psychological torment. Screenplay Wesley Strick, based on the screenplay by James R. Webb on the novel ‘The Executioners’ by John D. Macdonald. Bernard Herrmann’s original score has been adapted, arranged and conducted by Elmer Bernstein. Edited by Thelma Schoonmaker. Cinematography by Freddie Francis. Credits by Elaine and Saul Bass.

results.title: Cape Fear (1962) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: J Thompson, Sy Bartlett and Universal International Pictures
results.brief_description: Harrowing screen adaptation of John D. MacDonald’s novel ‘The Executioners’. Robert Mitchum is cast as the sadistic Max Cady, who has recently been released from prison and is determined to seek revenge on the lawyer who testified against him in a rape trial. Gregory Peck plays the targeted Savannah lawyer, Sam Bowden whose actions gradually spiral towards violence once Cady begins to harass his wife (Polly Bergen) and teenage daughter (Lori Martin). Unable to restrain Cady using legal methods, Bowden lures him to a remote location where he is free to confront him on equal terms. Cast includes: Martin Balsam, Jack Kruschen, Telly Savalas and Barrie Chase. Cinematography by Samuel Leavitt. Music by Bernard Herrmann. Screenplay by James R. Webb.

results.title: Quadrophenia
results.creator_credit: Franc Roddam, Bill Curbishley, Roy Baird, The Who Films and Polytel
results.brief_description: Jimmy (Phil Daniels) works in the post-office during the day in a job he hates. He lives for the weekends when he gets together with his mod friends, dresses up in sharp suits, pops amphetamine pills and dances to soul and power-pop in London clubs. The group of Mods decide to head down to Brighton for the weekend and while there, getting drunk and getting high on speed, they clash with a rival gang of working-class youth, the Rockers, whose musical tastes run to the legends of the fifties - Elvis, Bill Haley, Chuck Berry et. al. - and whose dress is blue-collar jeans and t-shirts. Set in 1965 and loosely based on The Who’s conceptual album of the same name, “Quadrophenia” is a kinetic film about youth culture, alienation and working class life. Featuring an explosive musical score by The Who, as well as great soul and rock music from the fifties and sixties, “Quadrophenia” is by turns both a perceptive and critical examination of leisure and work. Jimmy’s job confines him to a drudgery like that of his parents. It is a life that he wants to escape. He is free only through the exhilaration of music and drugs. With Sting, Toyah Willcox and Ray Winstone.

results.title: The Filth and the fury
results.creator_credit: Julien Temple, Amanda Temple, Anita Camarata, Nitrate Films and Jersey Shore
results.brief_description: This honest film is suitable for both fans of the band and social historians. The documentary traces the dramatic rise and fall of the Sex Pistols in 70s London, using a collage of interesting footage from the time of chaos and rebellion. Throughout the film Shakespeare’s “Richard III” is irreverently referred to as being emblematic of the Sex Pistols being a band created during a time ripe for rebellion and individuality. The band members are interviewed in the shadows as if to keep their current identities hidden. These members give a personal account - as a voice over - throughout the documentary, bringing to life the rare footage of the punk movement.

results.title: The Karate kid. Part 3
results.creator_credit: John G. Avildsen, Jerry Weintraub and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Hoping for a life of peace and tranquility selling bonsais, Daniel and Mr. Miyagi once again find themselves up against the odds. Going against Mr. Miyagi’s wishes, Daniel will defend his title in an All-Valley Championship match arranged by his nemesis, Kreese, whose karate studio folded after his star pupil lost to Daniel. This time Daniel must face ‘the bad boy of karate,’ Mike Barnes. When Mr. Miyagi refuses to train Daniel for the tournament, Daniel inevitably falls into the clutches of Terry (Kreese’s friend, unbeknownst to Daniel), who takes him on as a karate student. Cast includes: Ralph Macchio, Noriyuki Morita, Robyn Lively, Thomas Ian Griffith and Martin Kove.

results.title: Beyond the valley of the dolls
results.creator_credit: Russ Meyer and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Independent maverick, Russ Meyer, renowned for low-budget, transgressive porn and exploitation cinema, made his first studio film with “Beyond the valley of the dolls”. Teaming up with screenwriter Roger Ebert, today one of America’s most influential film critics, Meyer loosely based the film on the earlier “Valley of the dolls” (Mark Robson, 1967). An ambitious, uninhibited, all-girls rock band, starring Kelly (Dolly Read), Casey (Cynthia Myers), and Pet (Marcia McBroom), travel to L.A. with their manager, Harris (David Gurian), to visit Kelly’s aunt and claim an inheritance. A glamorous and successful woman in showbiz, Aunt Susan (Phyllis Davis), introduces the girls to producer and promoter, Z-Man (played superbly by John Lazar), who eventually leads them to phenomenal success. A sheer highlight of the film is the party sequence where the girls are introduced to this heady, topsy-turvy, circus-like world. Despite the surface frivolity, however, melodrama, horror, violence, and life-learning lessons await the three girls. Punchy dialogue, snappy editing, and great music make “Beyond the valley of the dolls” an entertaining film. And like exploitation cinema, often the corny plot lines and developments are fill-ins for outrageous visual action and energy. However, though its uninhibited attitude toward sex, nudity, and drug taking keeps it in line with hippy culture and exploitation cinema, the film’s moralistic finale and condemnation of non-heterosexual desire makes it conservative and a world away from the true values of the counter-culture.

results.title: An Officer and a gentleman
results.creator_credit: Taylor Hackford, Martin Elfand, Lorimar Film Entertainment and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Taylor Hackford (Against all odds, Proof of life) directed “An Officer and a gentleman”, starring Richard Gere and Debra Winger. It is the story of Zack Mayo (Gere) a man of uncertain future who is in conflict with his identity. A life of familial instability has left Zack unwilling to engage emotionally with others, especially women. Zack determines that he favours a career as a navy pilot, largely to prove to his alcoholic father that he is a son worthy of respect and capable of achievement. His steely demeanour suits military life but is in part broken down by his romance with a local factory girl Paula Pokrifi (Winger). Life in the armed forces is depicted as brutal and inhumane as the recruits make their way through a gruelling 13-week course. Foley, (Louis Gossett, Jnr) the irascible Major in charge of the recruits, rides Mayo particularly hard as he recognises in him Officer material. Mayo is torn between his cold conduct that shelters him from feeling anything and his burgeoning love for Paula. “An Officer and a gentleman” won Oscars for Gosset (Best Supporting Actor) and Best Song for “Up where we belong”.

results.title: Lolita
results.creator_credit: Adrian Lyne, Joel B Michaels, Mario Kassar and Lolita Productions Inc
results.brief_description: Following in the footsteps of Stanley Kubrick, Adrian Lyne brings to the screen the second film version of Vladimir Nabokov’s controversial 1955 novel “Lolita”. “Lolita” follows the exploits of bachelor Humbert Humbert (Jeremy Irons) who marries a jaded widow (Melanie Griffith), whom he secretly loathes, in order to get closer to his object of obsession, her teenage daughter, Lolita (Dominique Swain). Humbert’s obsession for Lolita takes them both to some dark sexual and psychological places. Following his wife’s timely death Humbert seizes the opportunity to take Lolita on a cross-country journey - one that tracks the sexual progression of the relationship between step-father and daughter. Having majored in erotic cinema in the past (Nine and a half weeks, Fatal attraction, Indecent proposal, Unfaithful) Adrian Lyne is well placed to deliver the sexual fantasies of Humbert to the big screen. Jeremy Irons is a nervous and manipulative Humbert, suffering guilt for his sexual fantasies even as he exploits Lolita in order to realise them. Dominique Swain is well cast as Lolita - the young nubile nymphette, only faintly aware of the intensity of her sexual power over the hapless Humbert. Original score by Ennio Morricone.

results.title: Top gun
results.creator_credit: Tony Scott, Jerry Bruckheimer, Don Simpson and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Directed by Tony Scott, “Top gun” was the film that catapulted Tom Cruise into mega stardom. Cruise plays Lieutenant Pete ‘Maverick’ Mitchell, a hotshot navy pilot, with no respect for rules, regulations or authority. Maverick is training at the Top Gun Naval Flying School, where he is out to prove himself to be the best of the best, at all costs. Maverick flies recklessly, but with skill, co-piloted by his best mate Nick ‘Goose’ Bradshaw (Anthony Edwards). Maverick is somewhat haunted by his father’s legacy, also a pilot, whose error whilst flying may have caused his own death and that of others. At the school Maverick encounters competition to be the top pilot from Lieutenant Tom ‘Iceman’ Kazanski (Val Kilmer) who mocks Maverick’s braggadocio and family history. Simultaneously Maverick is attracted to an instructor at the school, Charlie (Kelly McGillis) and is forced to face his personal demons in light of the strengthening feelings for her. “Top gun” features several daredevil flying scenes and has a sub-plot involving a run-in (mid-air) with some rogue Russian pilots. “Top gun” was the highest grossing film of 1986 in the United States. Also starring Tom Skerritt, as a flight instructor, and Meg Ryan as the Goose’s wife.
